title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement IHEID. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.0, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/0/ code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https:// www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing
text: Contributions manystates, whether form issue identification, bug fixes, new code documentation encouraged welcome: Submit issue Document existing code Fix bug implement new features Please note manystates project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project, agree abide terms.

title: Contributing
text: Please use issue tracker GitHub identify problems suggest new functionality, submitting changes code. use issues identify bugs tasks, discuss feature requests, track implementation changes. submitting issue, please provide least ‘Type’ label best describes issue . useful issues ones precisely identify bug, propose test pass instead fails.

title: Contributing
text: Another way contributing package developing vignettes/articles illustrate value added package. Please contact us directly proposals updating documentation, submit issue existing documentation unclear.

title: Contributing
text: Independent assigned code contributions welcome. writing new code, please follow tidyverse style guide based standard R guidelines. can help use packages lintr goodpractice ensure followed. styler package fixes non-invasive way code adhere tidyverse formatting rules, also provides RStudio Addins help task. run lintr goodpractice checks use styler file run: develop new code C++, please follow Google C++ Style Guide.
code: # basic lintr checking lintr::lint_package(path = "manystates/")  # goodpractices checks. Exclude length 80 goodpractice::gp(path = "globalgov/manystates/",    checks = all_checks()[-c(8)])  # styler fix some of the styling issues styler::style_file("filePath")

title: Contributing
text: use two main branches project: origin/master branch reserved fully functional releases model. develop branch reaches stable point, code maintainer merges back master branch, tags release number . origin/develop branch reflects latest model development stage. Contributers encouraged submit minor changes branch enhance existing functionality. New features may break existing functionality committed supporting branches. use two types supporting branches: Feature branches used develop new functionality. exist long feature developed, either merged develop branch incorporation release, deleted feature abandoned. Feature branches branch origin/develop. Hotfix branches used provide fixes severe bugs master branch. way, code maintainer incorporate (potentially unstable) changes develop branch fix issue. Branch names prefixed hotfix-. branching model based : https://nvie.com/posts/-successful-git-branching-model/.

title: Contributing
text: create release version code: Ensure repository --date: git pull. Switch master branch: git checkout master. Merge changes develop branch: git merge ---ff develop. Tag release version: git tag -VX.Y.Z -m "VERSION-NAME". Push changes repository git push origin master --tags.

what: Develop Branch (minor changes to existing functionality)
title: Contributing
text: make minor changes directly develop branch, follow standard git procedures: Make sure switched develop branch project: git checkout -b develop. Make sure local version code --date: git pull origin develop. Make changes Stage changes commit: git add PATH--CHANGED-FILE. Commit changes using appropriate message: git commit -m "DESCRIPTION". Push commit: git push origin develop.

title: Contributing
text: create new feature branch: git checkout -b myfeature develop. merge feature branch back develop:
code: git checkout develop git merge --no-ff myfeature git branch -d myfeature git push origin develop

what: Hotfix Branches (to fix critical bugs in release versions)
title: Contributing
text: create new hotfix branch: git checkout -b hotfix-VERSION master. merge hotfix back master (code maintainer ): develop: Every hotfix increment PATCH digit version number: hotfix branch V1.3.0 named hotfix-V1.3.1, new release tagged V1.3.1. merged master develop, hotfix branch can deleted: git branch -d hotfix-VERSION.
code: git checkout master git merge --no-ff hotfix-VERSION git tag -a VERSION git push origin develop git checkout develop git merge --no-ff hotfix-VERSION

title: Contributing
text: Commits relate existing issues reference updated status issues, mention issue number (preceded hash symbol: #) commit description: Resolved #31 adding new function things, also updated documentation issue hash (.e. #31) preceded resolve, resolves, resolved, close, closes, closed, fix, fixes, fixed (capitalised ), status issue(s) mentioned updated automatically. current syntactical standard mention issue first provide short description committed changes relation issue. ancillary changes can mentioned comma. written single line, like : #{verb} {issue} {describe main action/changes}, {additional actions/changes}.

title: Contributing
text: use testthat package write unit tests. convention, tests located testthat/tests/. verify tests pass issuing commit existing code. run tests latest version manually: writing new function, consider writing unit test function. follow several conventions writing tests: unit test file test one aspects single function. makes easier identify source bugs, prevents lower-level tests failing higher-level functions change. naming convention test files : test-FILENAME_IN_R_DIRECTORY-FUNCTION_NAME.R, .e. test files named file containing original function R directory, pre-fixed “test”, optionally post-fixed name function tested. test requires auxiliary functions package, e.g. initialize network sample data, belong helper file. one helper file R file, named helper-FILENAME_IN_R_DIRECTORY-FUNCTION_NAME.R. Re-using existing test data preferable creating new data every test.

title: Contributing
text: Note manystates package version according semantic versioning. means versions follow Major.Minor.Patch semantic format.

title: GGO states codebook

Note dataset constructed complement datasets Gleditsch Ward Revised List Independent States (manystates::states$GW) Butcher Griffiths’ International System(s) Dataset (manystates::states$ISD). , incomplete observations variables, yet offers specificity additional entries compared datasets. Work dataset supported Swiss National Science Foundation (SNSF) Grant Number 188976: “Power Networks Rate Change Institutional Complexes” (PANARCHIC). Please direct comments suggestions : James Hollway International Relations/Political Science Department Graduate Institute International Development Studies Geneva, Switzerland

title: GGO states codebook
text: three-letter code associated state state-like entity. three-letter codes based ISO 3166-1 alpha-3 list, codes consistent , however additional codes added cover historical states covered ISO’s list. possible, use Correlates War three-letter codes purpose, used GW ISD datasets. However, cases must select new codes situations, aim use recognisable, unique codes relying significant consonants vowels. Note endeavour use existing codes possible state episodes substantially similar territory involve inheritance international legal obligations, rights, recognitions predecessor states. reason series episodes associated “RUS”, example, ranging Russian Empire, USSR, Russian Federation. However, state considered legal successor state, example Serbia considered legal successor Yugoslavia, use different stateID codes (case “SRB” “YUG”). cases dissolution (see ), old stateID code cease, whereas cases secession, old stateID code continue rump state.

title: GGO states codebook
text: dates episode state independence deemed begun ended. Dates coded using messydates system. implements ISO’s extended date/time format. , dates entered year annotated question mark source uncertain. details see messydates. States currently independent end date 9999-12-31. distinguishes missing data, always coded NA.

title: GGO states codebook
text: basis coded episode state independence began. adopt many categories offered ISD dataset, add additional categories improve specificity: Consolidation: state created territory unified state previously existed, often uniting smaller local polities single entity Decolonisation: state born decolonisation empire colonial metropole, including conclusion protectorate trusteeship arrangement Dissolution: state born fragment larger state broke apart ceased exist (e.g. Austro-Hungarian Empire) Liberation: state restored period non-existence, example following occupation annexation (e.g. Belgium WWII occupation) Secession: state secedes breaks away larger state empire continues exist Transformation: state continues substance changes constitutional form, title, status without foreign conquest voluntary unification (e.g. Tsardom Russia 1721 Russian Empire) Unification: state born voluntary merging several (typically equally sized) states previously existed, e.g. UAE 1971 : unusual unclear cases; used sparingly explanation elaboration required comments code followed ? annotation, indicates uncertainty coding.

title: GGO states codebook
text: grounds coded state ended. use categories offered ISD dataset: Annexation: state taken conquest/foreign take-(e.g. Aceh 1874 Netherlands) Colonisation: state subjected imperial, non-contiguous colonisation, becomes protectorate, vassal (e.g. Mewar 1818 British protection) Unification: state ceases process voluntary unification incorporation (e.g. Croatia 1102 Hungary) Dissolution: state ceases dissolution state several smaller states (e.g. Gran Colombia 1830) Occupation: state ceases occupation outside powers (e.g. Albania Italy 1939) Partition: state ceases partition outside powers scission (e.g. Poland 1795) Revolution: state ceases internal revolution coup (e.g. Russian Empire 1917) Transformation: state continues substance changes constitutional form, title, status without foreign conquest voluntary unification (e.g. Tsardom Russia 1721 Russian Empire) : unusual unclear cases; used sparingly explanation elaboration required comments code followed ? annotation, indicates uncertainty coding.

Note use adjectival form, e.g. “Southern Africa”, distinguish region country “South Africa”. use “Central” describe areas middle continent, applicable. data includes following regions: Northern America Southern America Central America Caribbean America Northern Europe Eastern Europe Southeastern Europe Southern Europe Western Europe Central Europe Eastern Asia Southeastern Asia Southern Asia Western Asia Central Asia Northern Africa Eastern Africa Southern Africa Western Africa Central Africa Oceania

Please also check {manydata} information packages tools handle data many universe packages. addition, package includes several unique functions help work state data, including code_states() identify states within texts, generate_states() create fictional state names. package geared towards global governance research, can also used anyone interested state actors across time.

title: Many data on state and state-like actors in the international system
text: code_states() useful identifying states state-like entities within text data. non-trivial task, state names can vary widely spelling, abbreviation, context, many potential ambiguities (e.g., “Korea” refer North South Korea). function uses comprehensive library contemporary historical state names variants identify states given text. returns data frame identified states corresponding ISO 3166 alpha-3 codes standardised names. can handle single strings vectors strings. default identify first state mentioned text, possible search multiple states setting max_count argument value greater 1. function can currently discern 500 different states state-like entities. likely increase future releases, already 2.2 times next best package, states, instance.
code: manystates::code_states(c("The event took place in the United Kingdom.",              "Switzerland and New Zealand agreed that...",             "One of the oldest princely states is Chamba."),             max_count = 2) ## [1] "GBR"       "{CHE,NZL}" "CHM"

title: Code stateIDs from text — code_states
text: function allows contemporary historical countries states identified text. uses regular expression (regex) search number common names alternative spellings entity. function returns either three-letter abbreviation (extended version ISO-3166 alpha-3), name state. function can also return multiple matches, one country mentioned text. Currently, function can identify 500 entities. Updates, bug reports, suggestions welcome.

title: Code stateIDs from text — code_states
text: text vector text search country names within. code Logical whether function return three-letter abbreviation (extended version ISO-3166 alpha-3), name state. complete list entities search terms, run function without argument (.e. code_states()). Updates suggestions welcome. max_count Integer many countries search element vector. one country matched, countries returned set, .e. format "{AUS,NZL}". default max_count = 1, just return first match.

title: Code stateIDs from text — code_states
code: code_states(c("I went to England",   "I come from Venezuela",   "Did you know there was a Lunda Empire?",   "I like both Australia and New Zealand")) #> [1] "GBR" "VEN" "LUN" "AUS" code_states(c("I went to England",   "I come from Venezuela",   "Did you know there was a Lunda Empire?",   "I like both Australia and New Zealand"), max_count = 2) #> [1] "GBR"       "VEN"       "LUN"       "{AUS,NZL}"

title: Generate fictional country names — generate_states
text: function generates vector fictional country names. generated names designed resemble real country names, results match (least exactly) country names library provided. Please note function still experimental. names generated using Markov chain approach based syllable patterns found library real country names. function generate_states() uses syllabise_states() function split existing country names syllable-like units, providing special attention common patterns country names "land", "stan", "burg", others. transition matrix built syllable units, allowing generation new names mimic structure length real country names. Checks included ensure generated names unique, match existing country names, avoid certain uncommon patterns ending preposition. library country names provided, function defaults using comprehensive list country names {manystates} package. However, users can supply list country names customize generation process. function can useful creating fictional datasets testing, illustrative, pedagogical purposes. example, can used classroom exercises rely invented country names, -class simulations international relations negotiation, role-playing scenarios, mock data analysis tasks. Using fictional country names helps avoid unintended bias preconceptions associated real countries. can used creative writing game design. names might inspire fictional settings entities stories, games, creative works. name inspire unique culture, conflict, mythology. Writers use kickstart short stories, game designers might build entire maps quests around .

title: Generate fictional country names — generate_states
text: n Integer number country names generate library fictional country names. Default 10. countries Optional string vector country names use library generating fictional names. word One words (character vector) split syllable-like units.

title: Generate fictional country names — generate_states
text: String vector fictional country names

title: Generate fictional country names — generate_states
code: generate_states(12) #>  [1] "Blique Duchy E-Homburg"                #>  [2] "Sint"                                  #>  [3] "Choson"                                #>  [4] "Kitts Main The Lemy Cote France"       #>  [5] "Tonk Sabarbuda"                        #>  [6] "Nis Confoederate Darfur The Urambo Eu" #>  [7] "Shwa"                                  #>  [8] "Loum Of Duchy"                         #>  [9] "Mtetwa Arab"                           #> [10] "Zaire Kloengkoeng Of Mcdonald"         #> [11] "Den Te South Li Phi"                   #> [12] "Ssoulou"                                 syllabise_states("Afghanistan") #> [1] "af"   "gha"  "ni"   "stan"   syllabise_states("Saint Pierre and Miquelon") #>  [1] "saint" " "     "pie"   "rre"   " "     "and"   " "     "mi"    "que"   #> [10] "lon"

title: States datacube — states
text: manystates::states datacube list containing 3 datasets: ISD, GW, GGO. work--progress, please let us know comments suggestions.

title: States datacube — states
text: ISD: dataset 499 observations 36 variables: stateID, StateName, Begin, End, StateNameAlt, Latitude, Longitude, StartType, EndType, cowID, cowNR, ISD_Category, Region, Start_Am, EStart_Am, Declare, DecDate, Population, ..., VioEnd, VioEnd_Am. HUGGO: dataset observations  variables: . GW: dataset 216 observations 7 variables: stateID, StateName, Begin, End, StateNameAlt, cowID, cowNR. information references datasets used, please use manydata::call_sources() manydata::compare_dimensions() functions.

title: States datacube — states
text: Griffiths, Ryan D., Charles R. Butcher. 'Introducing international system(s) dataset (ISD), 1816-2011'. International Interactions 39.5 (2013), pp. 748-768. Gleditsch, Kristian S., Michael D. Ward. 'Interstate system membership: revised list independent states since 1816'. International Interactions 25.4 (1999), pp. 393-413. Hand-coded data GGO team

title: manystates 1.0.0
text: Dropped unnecessary dependencies CRAN submission Added description included data functions README (closed #78) Added funding details README Package still development considered stable (closed #76) Fixed code coverage Updated CITATION

title: manystates 1.0.0
text: Fixed GW preparation script $stateID coded correctly Added $StateNameAlt secondary labels parentheses Updated ISD version 2.2 Fixed ISD preparation script $Begin $End coded correctly Renamed states$HUGGO reflect new name dataset Simplified GGO preparation script exporting working clean csv Fixed current states ending 9999-12-31 (closed #85) Removed ~64 duplicated overlapping records (closed #84) Added details many states (closed #83, thanks @myevrard)

title: manystates 1.0.0
text: Now uses stringi exclusively Fixed Burgundy (BOU) identification code_states() (fixed #79) Fixed various negative lookup bugs regex patterns e.g. Korea Added 172 new regex patterns code_states() Added tests code_states() cover datasets states Added tests make sure ISO reserved codes assigned Added tests make sure states identified uniquely Now uses stringi exclusively Added syllabise_states() splitting state names syllables Improved state name generation algorithm based Markov chain syllables Improved state name generation algorithm better match length distribution real state names Added checks avoid generating existing, duplicate, awkward state names Added tests generate_states() Added filter_datacube() manydata filter state system given year (closed #77)

title: manystates 0.3.1
text: Moved code_states() function {manypkgs} user-facing Added code_states() website Improved regex matches code_states() Added tests code_states()

title: manystates 0.3.1
text: Closed #72 adding version 2 states$ISD Closed #64 filling missing state names states$HUGGO

title: manystates 0.3.0
text: Added package startup message Updated references database datacube Updated website, linking manytreaties manyigos Updated github workflows

title: manystates 0.3.0
text: Renamed states$HUGGO_STATES states$HUGGO Improved states$HUGGO adding missing state names Improved states$HUGGO adding missing latitude/longitudes, possible Improved country coding states$ICOW Added stateID datasets without variable using manypkgs::code_states() (closes #71) Renamed Beg variable Begin datasets (closes #67) Fixed RATRULES citation Dropped economic freedom dataset (closes #66) Reordered variables shared variables lead datasets Rearranged contiguity variables Renamed contiguity$HUGGO_CONT contiguity$HUGGO Renamed contiguity$COW_DIRCONT contiguity$COW Dropped additional variables contiguity$HUGGO duplicates states$HUGGO Updated related tests Improved variable mapping explanation (closes #68) Improved dataset documentation making computational Dropped leaders regimes

title: manystates 0.3.0
text: Dropped extract_cshapes() Dropped extract_vdem()

title: manystates 0.2.0
text: Closed #61 updating functions import Varieties Democracy data Github package standardised variable names. Updated import_vdem(), import_vparty(), import_cshapes() function fixing CMD warnings notes. Closed #54 moving code_states() {manypkgs} consistency across packages. Added first draft vignette publicize manystates data. Updated pkgdown.yml file

title: manystates 0.2.0
text: Closed #57 replacing GNEVAR datasets HUGGO datasets handcoded data states, leaders, contiguity databases. Added missing state names (StateName variable) regions (Region variable) HUGGO_STATES dataset.

title: manystates 0.1.0
text: Updated regex code_states() accurately match translate states’ names. Updated workflow files include package caching. Re-rendered documentation using messydates::mreport(). Added {cshapes} {vdemdata} dependencies

title: manystates 0.1.0
text: Closed #9 adding ICOW datasets states database. Closed #24 adding Economic Freedom datasets economics database. Closed #25 adding Freedom House data regimes database. Closed #48 adding data states’ ratification rules ratrules database. Closed #49 adding Colonial Relations data ICOW dataset colsrels database. Closed #50 adding self-coded data latitude longitude state capitals GNEVAR_STATES dataset states database. Closed #51 adding contiguity regions data FAO ICOW contiguity database.
